comments.commentBody: The corporations are afraid that the American people will find out what the President is willing to give up to make corporations happy.

You can't have trade deals at all without "fast track".
I agree with you about the TPP. But a TPP deal could be killed by Congress even with "fast track". The problem isn't "fast track", it's the fact that corporations seeking monopoly profits have too much influence over the Administration (and Congress, for that matter).

Why were negotiations done in secret?

What are corporations afraid of?

It is not just Obama.....It really took the SCREAMING from a majority of the U.S. population to get legislators to back off 'fast track'..(Dems at least).

And that was not done until someone involved had a change of conscience and leaked part of the treaty-to-be, the TPP - Trade Pilfering and Plundering....the peoples of the world to benefit the rich.

The excuse is always about cheaper goods. We already have enough cheap junk coming into this country from Asia. What we need is jobs & this agreement doesn't do it for us. It's all about corporate profits not the good of the people.

Fast track authority hands the President the right to decide which countries to negotiate with and what to negotiate. All agreements have to be ratified by a majority in both houses. The agreements can't be amended, filibustered or killed in committee. Presidents had this authority for a while; the act lapsed in 2007. Its scope goes beyond the TPP (trans-pacific partnership). The TPP itself has problems such as secrecy, ability of corporations to sue governments, and making generic drugs harder to come by. These are issues to be fixed, not issues to be used to throw all trade negotiations under the lumbering bus that is the Congress.

Manufacturing isn't the end goal for a country's future; improving quality of life is. Cheaper goods deter inflation and help everybody lead a better life. Growing income inequality is not from loss of manufacturing jobs; it is from an unwillingness to force a sharing of the pie. Blocking imports with tariffs and quotas is not going to remedy that situation. Companies are going to move manufacturing to lower-wage places with or without the TPP. Our focus has to be to replace those jobs with ones in the new economy and most importantly ensuring those jobs pay well. Holding onto the past will leave us behind a world getting richer by the year. A President without FTA has to go through our do-nothing Congress first for all trade negotiations. An up-and-down yes/no vote is more democratic than the backroom deals of committees and filibuster-land.

Mr. Spitzer...the negotiations are DONE and over with no input from the citizens/Congress!

Don't obfuscate, please. That is the issue - these two agreements have been in negotiation for years...behind closed doors. Now the proponents want them passed with no discussion or public knowledge...just like they were negotiated.

People who are conspiracy lovers may see a connection between all the policies being passed against demonstrations and public outcries as well as staffing up large penal facilities to protect those in power against those who would take to the streets with howling fury when they learn of the contents...already negotiated, Mr Spritzer

Blocking this "trade pact" is important.  Governments would be passing authority over to corporations to an extent that would not be accepted by the people if they were being properly informed.  Impeded is a beginning, but killing the trade pacts off is what we need.

MD Cooks, Check it again. http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/marriag...

How convenient for you to not read further in Oxford to sub-definition 1.1 "(in some jurisdictions) a formal union between partners of the same sex." You just take what suits your purpose and ignore the rest?

I have driven a car for some forty years, and blind spots apply mostly to issues off one's left shoulder or when you are backing up.

I know this much: when a driver is making a right turn, which means the pedestrian in that walkway -- in the path of your completed right turn --has the walk light. Blind spots have nothing to do with it.

There are more than a few NYC drivers that like to brush back the pedestrian who has the walk light and is beginning to cross the street. (Think Roger Clemens when Mike Piazza was at the plate.)

If the driver is obeying the law and paying attention, there is no issue of blind spots in this particular situation. If you can't see the pedestrian in question in this situation, you should (please!) take the bus.

Another commenter elsewhere in this strand has made the extremely important point that this study did not show that annual mammograms are not worthless.  It showed that mammograms are no better than annual breast exams by a trained nurse.

This study was based on mammograms performed between 1980 and 1985, and they were of poor quality, even by 1980 standards. There are multiple studies showing a definite decrease breast cancer mortality due to screening mammography. A combined analysis of all the studies together, even including this poor quality Canadian study, showed a definite decrease in breast cancer deaths in those women screened.
Most women will never get breast cancer. For those women, screening mammography will be useless. Unfortunately, you don't get to know ahead of time if you will develop breast cancer. About one in every 33 women will die from breast cancer. Out of those women destined to develop and die from breast cancer, regular screening mammography can save approximately 40%. These are the facts. Women need to decide for themselves whether it's worth the inconvenience, anxiety and discomfort, as well as a possible unnecessary biopsy, or even overtreatment of the cancer which would not have progressed during her lifetime. Many women believe that it is worth it in order for the chance to prevent an early and painful death. Others don't. Neither should be vilified or ever made to feel that it's their fault when they discover a lump which turns out to be an advanced breast cancer. Educate yourself and make your own decisions. Know that this article does not give the whole story. There is much much more data that absolutely proves that screening mammography saves lives.

The old scare tactics and veiled threats ("blood on your hands!") which have been used for decades to silence critics and keep women in the dark.
Thankfully, more women are aware these days and see straight through these statements.
When they can't handle the evidence they use the scary story and threats of preventable early death, whereas if they had a real point they'd deal with and refute the evidence (mounting ever higher) of no/little benefit with screening and high over-diagnosis. (and now it seems any benefit of screening is wiped out by deaths after treatments)
It's also, insulting that so many seem to think a scary story or threat is enough to keep most women in screening. Forget the evidence and real information on actual benefits and risks, it sounds a bit like, "do as you're told for your own good, we know what's best".
That doesn't cut it anymore...

Dr K,
There ARE some amazing doctors out there, I respect my GP and dermatologist, hand-picked after doctor-shopping.
I also, have enormous respect for the doctors who are fighting the medical system that violates our rights and risks/harms our health and well-being.
(Dr Gilbert Welch, Dr Margaret McCartney, Prof Michael Baum, Dr Peter Gotzsche and others)
A quick look at women's health forums shows the enormous worry and harm caused by the well-woman exam. It's of course, completely unnecessary and carries serious risk. Even ACOG can't justify the exam.
So many women can't access reliable birth control without submitting to unnecessary pelvic and breast exams or elective cancer screening.

So yes, I have a problem with those who abuse the rights and bodies of women.

Some women now "manage" health problems (asthma, diabetes etc.) or go without the Pill (or get their pills online or make a trip to Mexico) because they fear the coercion/pressure of the consult room or they've been sacked by their doctor for non-compliance. We're all entitled to respectful and ethical medical care, and all screening is elective, says the law and proper ethical standards.

No, you're not all evil monsters and I understand many doctors feel compromised, but there is a SERIOUS problem with the way women are viewed and treated by the medical system. We all need to address it, reject it, speak out and force change.

The only difference between the control group and study group in the Sweedish trial was whether or not the participants were invited for screening mammography. Both groups of women saw their health care providers for physical examination as they normally would,
The breast cancer death rate is higher in Denmark than in Sweden because of high quality screening in Sweden.

When you have 10 governments in there with so many layers it is very difficult to invest and for privatization to expand. Root of the problem is Serb republic and Bosniak-Croat federation. Never understood that federation anyway. There is only about 150 thousand Croats in there, max 200 000. Seems like everything was done to undermine majority Bosniaks at those peace conferences. Thats why gettings rid of entities is the key. Bosnia for all without borders and muliple governments. Time for US (the culrpit) and Europe (which never cared that genocide was occuring in Bosnia) to step it up and eliminate those obstacles that are Blocking Bosnia from being a succesful country.

Bosnia's problems aren't just political. Its per-capita GDP is 1/4th the EU average; raising standard of living requires more than railing against or even replacing incompetent leaders. The three major groups eye one another with hostility and suspicion; infrastructure destroyed in the war has still not been rebuilt to a large extent; the country remains predominantly rural. The influence of Tito stays strong in the region and privatization has been half-hearted: http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2002/11/2061523/bosnia-herzego...

Even in America there is no absolute freedom of speech, as a Supreme Court justice once said, "you cannot shout 'fire' in a crowded theatre." Religion is an extremely delicate subject, no matter what religion we are talking about. When Hindus see their religion made a mockery of in a variety of ways -- whether by M.F. Hussain in his paintings showing Indian deities in a nude form. Western intellectuals reducing Hinduism to animal worship or Ms. Doniger portraying Hinduism as nothing more than a sexually titillating belief system, we are provoking a religious community that has been remarkably peaceful and kept its religion to itself rather than pushing it down the throats of non-Hindus. Compare that with the history of other major religions in the world. So perhaps, authors like Ms. Doniger should celebrate this religion for the tolerance it has taught to the world. Perhaps, we should have more authors like the philosopher S. Radhakrishnan, who provided internationally acclaimed treatises on what Hinduism is all about.

"India's liberal values or its commitment to free speech"
"Peaceful protest"

The facts are not so serene ...

At a 2003 lecture in London, Wendy Doniger had an egg thrown at her and "faced a barrage of insults from a group who had come with the egg-thrower, and who maintained that as a non-Hindu she was unqualified to comment on their religion."

The Indian historians D.N. Jha and Romila Thapar have received death threats.

India: The War Over History
William Dalrymple
April 7, 2005
http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2005/apr/07/india-the-war-over-...

The people of the US did not have a history of religious strife. For the most part, here it is history of violent racism.

So, the laws concerning slander along religious lines is less stringent, but along racial lines is much worse. And now that is extended to other newly earned freedoms, such as gay/lesbian. You make a ill advised joke or slur on those lines, your show is canceled on the TV, you are ostracized, and called named. Freedom of speech of that person? Not much according to the same PC crowd that is now turning on India.

On the other hand, India suffered serious religious strife for several centuries, during partition, and in the years since independence. The smallest incidents get blown up and lead to mass violence. Does it bother people here? Does it bother them if several thousands die in a india? Not really - what. Do they care about deaths in a dirt poor third world country? But they feel free to lecture India that freedom of speech must be respected, to satisfy their own sensibilities, regardless of consequences for India.

That is what you get from the leftist hypocrites of the west.

You're referring to very different issues, here.

Burning things is not immediately an issue of free speech, but rather of free expression. It has more limited protections, for obvious reasons. Defecation in public, for example, may be done for exclusive purposes, but a law restricting that act will not violate the first amendment. Further, there are no US laws, to my knowledge, that ban burning of Holy books.

And the first amendment really only protects against government laws restricting speech and press, though there are a few exceptions. Employers, such as the US military, can institute rules that place reasonable limits on speech, and private individuals can make rules banning lots of kinds of speech in their home. Further, political figures are welcome to condemn things they don't like, as long as they make no law.

So, what is the difference between some Hindus taking offense at this book (as many Muslims with The Satanic Verses, or the Danish Cartoons) and the US State Department and many in America stopping the burning of the Koran by that fundamentalist preached in Florida, which after all was also his right to free speech?

In America there is freedom of speech as long as you don't take on the new holy cows here, big oil, the military industrial complex, the big banks and so on. You take those people on, prepare to get denigrated and attacked into submission by all kinds (think occupy movement for example).
As far as this book goes, I certainly remember reading excerpts that seemed to me designed to mock the Hindu religion and India in general. So the reaction from India is not surprising.
If I were paranoid I'd think there is a bigger game of riling up yet another religion that is not Christianity at play here. But I am not paranoid.... yet!

Actually, the one-star reviews are in the lead (67/120 ATM):
http://www.amazon.com/The-Hindus-An-Alternative-History/dp/014311669X/

a quote from page 1 of Wendy Doniger's book will give you some idea of Batra doesn't like it: "Part of my agenda in writing an alternate history is to show how much the groups that conventional wisdom says were oppressed and silenced and played no part in the development of the tradition - women, pariahs (oppressed castes, sometimes called untouchables) did actually contribute to Hinduism.

We're talking dirty laundry here folks. Thanks Batra, for alerting the entire world to these issues.

What part of Professional Football Player don't the players understand.  After 4 years of college, they are acting like second graders.  They are paid very well to be PROFESSIONALS - on and off the field.  If they can't act like a pro, then cut them.  They have no place among real men.

Interesting, but in sicily, for example, men are socially very affectionate with each other. Is this not an expression of the erotic? As I understand it, nevertheless, gay men are still not accepted, or is homophobia something stronger?

"Respect for women"?

Yes, that's the missing "component", ain't it, Rdean? A very strange but revealing "analysis"...

Well, we're heading full steam back to the ancient world, for sure. The very definition of which was: misogyny, all the way down.

Wow, I can't say it any better than that, RDeanNYC. However, I disagree with the article that the desire to win will overcome feelings of homophobia in the players. For one thing, there are equally good players standing several ranks deep for every one who's admitted to the NFL. Often the difference is a tiny fraction of a second or a minuscule statistical advantage. And it's impossible to quantify the "heart" that is needed for a successful NFL career; very subjective, and often assessed wrongly, as we see. Secondly, the common homophobia is deeply ingrained from an early age and is a part of the individual character, in many cases, as well as the group culture. That's a powerful combination.

Thank you for having the courage to point out that close male groups have, inherently, a homoerotic component.  This doesn't mean that such a group's members are gay, but rather that sexual energy, indeed, same-sex closeness, is both erotic and social.  The denial of this fact is the source of homophobia.  Doubtless, you will get flak for this one statement, since the homophobic culture that privileges heterosexual males, cannot abide the idea that emotional and sexual energy are related, especially in same-sex groups.  More and more the sexuality of any individual is being seen not only as generalized attraction, but as the expression of one's romantic aspirations.  To the extent that straight men, whatever their intensely homosocial bonding behavior is in the locker room, can also define their sexuality as an aspiration for the person each of them loves, the acceptance of gays in traditionally straight male bonding groups might help women get more respect, too.  "Straight" might come to mean the desire for an opposite-sex special someone, rather than a proclivity to objectify and demean women as a whole group.

El wrongo.  One way of teaching respect is by starting in childhood, certainly. But if you genuinely believe that's the only way, I'd completely give up on the human race. Most people can be taught in adulthood things that were missing in their upbringing. Otherwise, you might as well execute every convicted murderer, rapist, embezzler. Why bother with prison if they can't be taught how to respect others?

Thank you for mentioning the college dorms. As a young woman I attended a private girls college. I was bullied terribly by a group on my floor. Each was a cruel bully. Thankfully I met a wonderful friend who showed me kindness and friendship when needed most.

What did I take away from that experience?
We need to protect children from this kind of behavior.

As a grammar school teacher I try hard to be sensitive to the needs of all my children. I do not hesitate to stop such behavior in its tracks and encourage kindness and inclusion. I have even become aware when a bullys behavior is the angry response from being bullied in their own home. They too can thrive and heal in a safe non critical place.

I am blessed to teach such wonderful children. As their art teacher you would be amazed what you discover about a child just through their art, colors, interaction and at times frustration with materials. Since all adults start out as a young child,
maybe the Dolphins need a good art therapist..... I'm available.

It was bullying, David. Incognito has an ugly history including getting kicked out off of two college teams, expelled from those colleges, harassing females at team sponsored golf outings, drunken temper/ steroid tantrums in public (on film, no less). The dude is bad news. He deserves every ounce of blame coming his way.
you have the facts, READ THE REPORT.

So far doesn't sound like bullying to me. It is human nature to begin judging before we have all the facts, but we really should resist that and wait until we read the report, hear from everyone, including Incognito, Martin and other players about what happened. We need to see the texts too.  What am I saying? From the comments below it sounds like people came to a conclusion based on their own life experiences and prejudices long ago.

NFL players are not a random sample of males. That they select to engage in and like a violent game would have implications for many other behaviors. Jocks and nerds have quite different personality constellations. (Not all.)

Surprise! Surprise!
